title: Food Preparation — Banana Slicing
description: The child learns to slice a banana using a child-safe knife. This exercise develops coordination, sequencing, and the independence of preparing one's own snack.
instructions:
1. Wash hands together.
2. Place a banana, cutting board, child-safe knife, and plate on a tray.
3. Demonstrate peeling the banana: pull back each section of peel.
4. Show how to hold the knife safely with the dominant hand and steady the banana with the other.
5. Slice slowly, pressing down and forward.
6. Arrange slices on the plate. Enjoy the snack!

slides.heading: Food Preparation
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at this! This is our special lesson where we get to be little chefs and make our very own yummy snack. We are going to learn how to get a banana all ready to eat by ourselves!

slides.setup_instructions: Wash hands first. Place all materials on a tray. Have a waste bowl ready for the peel.
slides.mascot_explanation: Yay, it's time to get our tools ready for our banana snack! We need a soft banana, a safe knife just for kids, a flat board to cut on, and a little plate for our yummy slices. Can you ask a grown-up to help you find all these things and put them on a tray?

slides.text: 'Today we are going to prepare our own snack! First, let's peel the banana.' Show how to pull back each strip of peel.
slides.mascot_explanation: First, we need to get our banana ready! See how you can pull down the skin, like a little blanket? Let's peel the whole banana down so we can eat it.

slides.text: Place the peeled banana on the cutting board. 'Hold the knife in this hand. Keep your other fingers away from the blade.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now we put our yummy banana on the cutting board. We hold the safe knife with one hand, and we'll use our other hand to hold the banana still, away from the sharp part. We have to be super careful with our fingers!

slides.text: Demonstrate one slow slice: press the knife down and forward. 'See how the slice falls? Your turn!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Watch me! We're going to push the knife down gently and a little bit forward, like we're giving the banana a little hug. See how it makes a perfect circle? Now it's your turn to try making a slice!

slides.text: 'Slice the whole banana. Take your time — there is no rush. Put each slice on the plate.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Let's keep slicing our banana, one piece at a time, all the way down. Take your time and be gentle, just like we practiced. When you make a slice, we'll put it right on our plate.

slides.prompt: Slice the entire banana. Arrange the slices nicely on your plate. How many slices did you make?
slides.mascot_explanation: You did it! You sliced the whole banana all by yourself and made it look so pretty on your plate. Can you count how many yummy banana slices you made for your snack?

slides.text: Enjoy your snack! Then wash the cutting board, knife, and plate. Put the peel in the compost or trash.
slides.mastery_check: Can the child safely peel and slice a banana with minimal assistance?
slides.mascot_explanation: Hooray, you made your own snack! Enjoy eating those delicious banana slices you cut. Remember to help clean up by washing your tools and putting the banana peel in the trash or a special compost bin. You're such a great helper!

parent_notes: Food preparation is a cornerstone of Montessori practical life. Using a real knife (even a butter knife) teaches respect for tools and builds confidence. Always supervise closely but avoid hovering. Bananas are ideal for first cutting because they are soft and require minimal force. The child may eat the slices as a natural reward for their work.

title: Sandpaper Letters — Review and Remaining: j, z, q
description: Introduction to three less common sandpaper letters: j, z, and q. These complete the child's exposure to the full alphabet of sandpaper letters.
instructions:
1. Quick review of all previously learned letters (lay out 10, child names each sound).
2. Introduce 'j': trace and say /j/ (as in 'jump'). Three-period lesson.
3. Introduce 'z': trace and say /z/ (buzzing sound). Three-period lesson.
4. Introduce 'q': trace and say /kw/ (always with 'u'). Three-period lesson.
5. Mix new and old letters for recognition practice.
6. I Spy for /j/ and /z/ sounds.
materials_needed: Small objects starting with j and z

slides.heading: Sandpaper Letters
slides.mascot_explanation: Look at this fun title slide! It tells us we're going to learn some special letter sounds that are a little tricky, like the sounds in "jump," "buzz," and "queen." We're going to have so much fun with them!

items: Objects: jar, jet, zoo animal, zipper
slides.setup_instructions: Place new letters face-down. Have review letters and objects ready.
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at all these things we need! We have some special bumpy letters, and some cool things like a jar and a zipper. We'll use these to help us learn our new letter sounds and practice tracing them. Ask your grown-up to help you find them all!

slides.text: Review: lay out 10 learned letters. Child traces each and says the sound. Celebrate confidence!
slides.mascot_explanation: Now, let's look at some letters we already know. Remember how we trace them and say their sounds? We're going to do that again to get our brains ready for our new letters. You're so good at this!

slides.text: Introduce 'j': trace with two fingers. '/j/ — like jump and jar!' Three-period lesson.
slides.mascot_explanation: This is our letter 'j'! Feel how bumpy it is? Let's trace it with our fingers, just like this. Say it with me: /j/, /j/, /j/, like in "jump" or a yummy "jar"! Great job!

slides.text: Introduce 'z': trace and say /z/ — 'like a buzzing bee! Zzzzz.' Three-period lesson.
slides.mascot_explanation: Here's another new letter, 'z'! Trace it with me. This letter makes a buzzing sound, like a busy bee! Can you make that sound? Zzzzz! That's right, /z/, /z/, /z/! You're doing so well!

slides.text: Introduce 'q': 'This letter almost always comes with u. Together they say /kw/ — like queen and quilt.'
slides.mascot_explanation: This is the letter 'q', and it almost always holds hands with the letter 'u'. When they are together, they make a special sound: /kw/, /kw/, /kw/, like in "queen" or a cozy "quilt." Let's say it together!

slides.prompt: I Spy: find objects that start with /j/ and /z/. Then trace all three new letters in the sand tray.
slides.mascot_explanation: It's time to play a game! We're going to pretend to be detectives and find things that start with our new sounds, /j/ and /z/. Then, we get to trace our new letters, j, z, and q, in the sand tray – how fun!

slides.text: 'You are learning ALL the sounds of the alphabet! Soon you will know every single one.'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child trace and produce the sounds /j/, /z/, and /kw/?
slides.mascot_explanation: Yay! You learned all the new letter sounds today! You traced j, z, and q, and you know their sounds! You are becoming such a super reader and writer, and you know so many letters now!

parent_notes: These are among the last sandpaper letters introduced because they are less frequent in English. The /q/ sound is unusual because it always pairs with 'u' to make /kw/. Don't worry about mastery of all 26 letters at once — the child will continue to review throughout the year. Celebrate that the child has now been exposed to the complete alphabet!

title: Teen Boards — Introduction (11-13)
description: Introduction to the Montessori teen boards. The child learns how teen numbers are formed by combining a ten and additional units. Starting with 11, 12, and 13.
instructions:
1. Present the teen board (a board with printed '10' slots where a digit card slides over the 0).
2. Place the 10 bead bar next to the board.
3. Slide the '1' card over the zero: 'Now it says 11.' Place one unit bead next to the ten bar.
4. Count: 'Ten and one more is eleven.'
5. Repeat with 12 and 13.
6. Three-period lesson: 'This is twelve. Show me thirteen. What number is this?'

slides.heading: Teen Boards
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at this! Today we're going to learn about some super special numbers that come after ten. They're called "teen" numbers, and we'll start with 11, 12, and 13!

slides.setup_instructions: Place the teen board on a mat. Have ten bars and unit beads in a tray nearby.
slides.mascot_explanation: Let's get our special math toys ready! We have a board that helps us make teen numbers, some little number cards, a long string of ten beads, and some single beads. Go find these with a grown-up so we can play!

slides.text: 'You know numbers 1 to 10. Now we are going to learn numbers that come AFTER ten! These are called teen numbers.'
slides.mascot_explanation: You already know numbers 1 through 10, right? That's so great! Today, we're going to learn about the numbers that come right after ten, the fun "teen" numbers!

slides.text: Point to the board showing '10.' 'This says ten. Watch what happens when I slide this card.' Slide '1' over the 0. 'Now it says ELEVEN — 11!'
slides.mascot_explanation: See this board? It shows a big '10'. Now, watch this magic card! When we put this '1' card here, it changes the '10' to make it say ELEVEN! That's 11!

slides.text: Place a ten bar and one unit bead beside it. 'See? Ten and one more is eleven.' Count the beads: 'Ten... eleven!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Look, we have our ten beads, and we add just one more little bead. When we put them together, we have ten beads and one more, which makes eleven! Ten and one makes 11!

slides.text: Slide '2' over: 'TWELVE — ten and two more!' Place ten bar and 2 unit beads. Then do thirteen.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now we slide a different card, the '2', and it makes the number TWELVE! See? It's ten beads and two more beads. Then we can do the same for thirteen – ten beads and three more!

slides.prompt: Build 11, 12, and 13 with the beads. Then play: I say a number, you build it on the board and with beads!
slides.mascot_explanation: It's time to play! Let's build the numbers 11, 12, and 13 using our beads and the board. Then, I'll say a number, and you can build it for me! You can do it!

slides.text: 'Eleven, twelve, thirteen — each one is ten plus some more! We will learn more teen numbers this week.'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child form and name 11, 12, and 13 using the teen board and beads?
slides.mascot_explanation: We did it! We learned that eleven, twelve, and thirteen are all made by taking ten and adding a little bit more. That's how we make those special teen numbers! You were so good at building them!

parent_notes: The teen board is a brilliant Montessori material that makes the confusing teen numbers concrete. Children can SEE that 13 is a ten and three ones. The irregular names (eleven, twelve) are harder than the regular pattern (thirteen = three-teen). Be patient with these. Using the bead bars alongside the board connects quantity to symbol.

title: Constructive Triangles — First Box Review and Discoveries
description: Revisiting the blue constructive triangles to discover all possible shapes that can be made, recording findings in a geometry journal.
instructions:
1. Open the blue constructive triangles box.
2. Take out two right-angled triangles of equal size.
3. Match the black lines together. 'What shape did we make?' (A rectangle!)
4. Continue with other pairs: two form a square, two form a larger triangle.
5. Let the child explore different combinations.
6. Name the resulting shapes.

slides.heading: Constructive Triangles
slides.subheading: Constructive Triangles — First Box Review and Discoveries
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at this! We're going to play with special triangle shapes today and see what amazing things we can build. It’s like a fun puzzle!

slides.setup_instructions: Place all triangles from the box on the mat, scattered gently.
slides.mascot_explanation: See this box? It has all our triangle friends inside, and we have a special mat for them to play on. We need to get them all out so we can start our building adventure!

slides.text: 'These are all triangles. But did you know we can combine triangles to make OTHER shapes? Let's discover!'
slides.mascot_explanation: These are all triangles, but guess what? We can put them together to make brand new shapes, like magic! Let's see what shapes we can discover together.

slides.text: Take two matching right-angled triangles. 'See the black lines? When we put the black lines together...' Join them. 'A rectangle!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now, let's find two triangles that look exactly the same. See those dark lines? We'll put those lines together. Poof! We made a rectangle, just like a door!

slides.text: Try another pair: 'These two make a square!' And another: 'These make a bigger triangle!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Let's try some more! We can put two other triangles together to make a square, like a window! And look, two more can make an even bigger triangle. So cool!

slides.text: 'Triangles are building blocks for many shapes. Every shape can be made from triangles!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Isn't that neat? Triangles are like super building blocks for all sorts of shapes! It’s like they are the smallest pieces that make everything else.

slides.prompt: Match all the pairs by their black lines. How many different shapes can you make? Name each one!
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it’s your turn to be a super builder! Try putting different triangles together and see what new shapes you can make. Can you name the shapes you build? You have lots of time to play and discover!

slides.text: Return all triangles to the box. 'Triangles are the building blocks of geometry!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child combine triangles to form at least 3 different shapes?
slides.mascot_explanation: You did such a wonderful job building shapes with the triangles! You learned that triangles are like little building blocks for big shapes. Remember how you made that awesome rectangle? You're a geometry superstar!

parent_notes: The constructive triangles reveal one of geometry's great secrets: any polygon can be divided into triangles. This is deep mathematical thinking presented as a simple puzzle! The black lines guide the child to correct pairings. Once mastered with lines, future work removes the lines and the child must figure out combinations independently. If you don't have official materials, cut triangles from colored cardboard.

title: Read-Aloud: The Tiny Seed by Eric Carle
description: Reading 'The Tiny Seed' by Eric Carle, exploring the life cycle of a plant through the seasons. This connects to the science curriculum on plant life cycles.
instructions:
1. Show the cover. 'What do you see? What might this story be about?'
2. Read slowly, pointing out the collage illustrations.
3. Pause at each season: 'What season is it now in the story?'
4. Discuss the challenges the seeds face: too hot, too cold, eaten by birds.
5. 'What happened to the tiny seed? It survived and grew into a beautiful flower!'
6. Connect to real life: 'What seeds have you planted?'
materials_needed: The Tiny Seed by Eric Carle
Optional: real seeds to hold during the story

slides.heading: Read-Aloud
slides.subheading: The Tiny Seed by Eric Carle
slides.mascot_explanation: Look at this picture! It's the cover of our book, and it's called "The Tiny Seed." It has a little seed on it, and I wonder what will happen to it in our story today!

slides.setup_instructions: Sit together comfortably. If you have seeds, let the child hold one during the story.
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, we get to read a special book! We need our book, and a super comfy spot to sit together. If you have some real tiny seeds, you can hold one while we read, just like the seed in our story!

slides.text: Show the cover: 'This is called The Tiny Seed. What do you think will happen to this little seed?'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now we're going to look at the front of our book, called the cover. The grown-up is going to ask you what you see and what you think our story might be about. Let's look closely at the little seed!

slides.text: Read slowly. At each season, pause: 'Now it's autumn. What's happening to the seeds?'
slides.mascot_explanation: We're going to read our story super slowly so we don't miss anything. When we get to a new season, like when it's cold or warm, we'll stop and talk about what's happening to the seeds. What do you think happens when the weather changes?

slides.text: Discuss the dangers: 'Oh no! One seed flew too high near the sun. One landed on ice. What happened to them?'
slides.mascot_explanation: Oh no, it looks like some seeds had some tricky times! The grown-up will ask you what happened to the seeds that were too hot or too cold, or got eaten. Let's think about how the little seed stayed safe.

slides.prompt: After reading: 'What does a seed need to grow? Can you put the seasons in order: fall, winter, spring, summer?'
slides.mascot_explanation: After our story, we'll talk about what a little seed needs to grow big and strong! Then, we'll play a game where we put the seasons in the right order: fall, winter, spring, and summer. Can you help me remember the order?

slides.text: 'The tiny seed grew into a giant flower! Even small things can become something big.'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child retell the basic sequence of the seed's journey through the seasons?
slides.mascot_explanation: Our story is all done, and the tiny seed grew into a beautiful flower! That means even little things can turn into something really big and amazing. You did such a great job listening and learning with me today!

parent_notes: This book beautifully connects to the science curriculum on plant life cycles. Eric Carle's collage art style is wonderful for children. The story teaches perseverance — the tiny seed survives when bigger seeds do not. Consider planting a real seed after reading this book so the child can observe the life cycle firsthand.

title: Binomial Cube — Introduction
description: Introduction to the binomial cube as a sensorial puzzle. The child assembles the cube by matching colors and shapes, building spatial reasoning and preparing for future algebra.
instructions:
1. Open the binomial cube box. Remove the lid and show the completed cube.
2. Carefully lift the cube out and place on the mat.
3. Gently separate the top layer. Name the colors: 'Red cube, red-and-black prism, red-and-blue prism.'
4. Rebuild the top layer following the painted pattern on the box lid.
5. Separate and rebuild the bottom layer.
6. The child practices rebuilding one layer at a time.

slides.heading: The Binomial Cube
slides.mascot_explanation: Look at this colorful box! It has a special name, the Binomial Cube, and it's like a super fun 3D puzzle waiting for us to play with. We're going to discover something amazing inside!

slides.setup_instructions: Place the box on a mat. The painted pattern on the lid and sides serves as the control of error.
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, this is our special puzzle box! Inside is our big puzzle, the binomial cube. See the pretty colors and shapes painted on the box? That's going to be our special helper to build our puzzle later!

slides.text: 'This is the binomial cube. It's like a beautiful 3D puzzle! Let's see what's inside.' Open the box.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now, let's open up our special box very carefully. We want to see the wonderful puzzle that's hiding inside! Are you ready to peek?

slides.text: Lift out the cube carefully. Point to the colors: 'Red cube, blue cube, and prisms of red-black and blue-black.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Whoa, look at that! This is our binomial cube! We have big colorful blocks, like a red one and a blue one, and some pieces that have two colors, like red and black, or blue and black.

slides.text: Separate ONLY the top layer. 'The lid shows us the pattern. Let's match the colors and rebuild this layer.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Let's gently take off just the top part of our puzzle. See how the lid has a picture? That picture is like a secret map that will show us exactly where each colorful piece goes!

slides.text: Place each piece following the painted guide on the box lid. 'Red cube in the corner, then the matching prisms beside it.'
slides.mascot_explanation: We're going to use the picture on the lid like a guide. We'll put the red block here, and then find the pieces that match its colors right next to it, just like following a treasure map!

slides.prompt: Take apart the top layer and rebuild it. Then try the bottom layer. Can you put the whole cube back together?
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's your turn to be the puzzle master! Try taking the top part apart and then putting it back together using our special picture guide. Then, you can try the bottom part too! You can do it!

slides.text: Close the box with the completed cube inside. 'You solved the binomial cube!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child rebuild at least one layer of the binomial cube using the painted guide?
slides.mascot_explanation: Yay! You put the puzzle back together! You closed the box with the whole cube inside, which means you solved the amazing binomial cube puzzle. You did such a great job matching all the colors and shapes!

parent_notes: The binomial cube is a sensorial material that indirectly represents the algebraic formula (a+b) cubed. At this age, the child works with it purely as a 3D puzzle. The painted pattern on the box serves as the control of error — the child can self-correct. Never explain the algebra; let the child simply enjoy the puzzle. Mastery comes through repetition over weeks and months.

title: Moveable Alphabet — Introduction
description: Introduction to the Montessori moveable alphabet. The child learns how to find letters in the compartments and begins building simple three-letter words.
instructions:
1. Present the moveable alphabet box. Show the organization: each letter has its own compartment.
2. 'These letters are for BUILDING words. Let's build some!'
3. Say the word 'cat' slowly: /k/-/a/-/t/. 'What's the first sound?'
4. Child finds 'c' in the box. Then 'a'. Then 't'. Arrange on the mat: cat.
5. Build 3-4 more CVC words: mat, sat, pin, dog.
6. Child reads each word back after building.

slides.heading: The Moveable Alphabet
slides.mascot_explanation: Look at this! We are going to learn about building words with special letter pieces. It's like having magic letters that can make any word we say!

items: Optional: miniature objects to match words
slides.setup_instructions: Place the moveable alphabet on a table. Lay a mat below for word building.
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at all these little letter pieces! We have a special box for them, and a big mat to put our words on. You might even have little toys to match our words later!

slides.text: 'This is the moveable alphabet! Every letter has its own home in the box. Let's explore it.'
slides.mascot_explanation: See this special box? It's full of letters, and each letter has its own special spot, like its own little house! Let's open it up and see all the letters inside.

slides.text: Show the child how to find letters: 'Here are all the a's. Here are all the t's. We can use them to build words!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Look, here are all the 'a's together, and here are all the 't's! We can pick out the letters we need to build words, just like picking out toys to play with.

slides.text: Say 'cat' slowly: /k/-/a/-/t/. 'What sound do you hear first?' Child finds 'c.' 'Next sound?' Find 'a.' 'Last sound?' Find 't.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Let's say "cat" together, super slow: /k/-/a/-/t/. What's the first sound you hear? That's right, it's 'c'! Now let's find that letter. What sound comes next?

slides.text: Arrange on mat left to right: c-a-t. 'You built CAT! Can you read it back to me?'
slides.mascot_explanation: We found all the letters for "cat"! Now we put them on the mat, like this: c-a-t. Yay, you built the word "cat"! Can you read it back to me?

slides.prompt: Build these words: mat, sat, pin, dog. Sound each word out first, then find the letters. Read each word when done!
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's your turn to be a word builder! Let's make the words "mat," "sat," "pin," and "dog." We'll say the sounds slowly, find the letters, and then read our amazing words!

slides.text: Return all letters to their compartments. 'You are a word builder! You can write with the moveable alphabet!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child sound out and build at least 3 CVC words with the moveable alphabet?
slides.mascot_explanation: You did it! You put all the letters back in their homes. You are such a super word builder and can make so many words with these letters! That was so much fun!

parent_notes: The moveable alphabet is one of the most important Montessori language materials. It allows the child to 'write' before their hand is ready for pencil writing. The key skill is segmenting — breaking a spoken word into its individual sounds. Don't worry about perfect spelling at this stage; phonetic attempts are celebrated. The child may spell 'cat' as 'kat' — this shows strong phonetic thinking!

title: Teen Boards — 14, 15, 16
description: Continuing with the teen boards: learning to form and name 14, 15, and 16 with the board and golden beads.
instructions:
1. Review 11, 12, 13 with the teen board.
2. Build 14: slide '4' card, place ten bar and 4 unit beads. 'Fourteen — ten and four!'
3. Build 15: slide '5' card, place beads. 'Fifteen — ten and five!'
4. Build 16: slide '6' card, place beads. 'Sixteen — ten and six!'
5. Three-period lesson for all six teen numbers.
6. Random practice: 'Build fifteen!' 'What number is this?'

slides.heading: Teen Boards
slides.mascot_explanation: Look at this! We're going to learn about some super special numbers today, called "teen numbers." They're bigger than ten and have their own cool names!

slides.setup_instructions: Set up the teen board on a mat. Have beads ready in a tray.
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at all these neat things we get to play with! We have a special board, little cards with numbers on them, and some shiny beads – one big bar of ten and some little ones. We'll use these to build our new numbers.

slides.text: Review: 'Let's remember our teen numbers!' Build 11, 12, 13 quickly with the board and beads.
slides.mascot_explanation: Let's remember the numbers we already know! We're going to quickly make numbers eleven, twelve, and thirteen using our board and beads. It's like a quick warm-up for our math muscles!

slides.text: Build 14: slide the '4' over the zero. Place a ten bar and 4 unit beads. 'Ten and four — FOURTEEN!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now we get to make a brand new number: fourteen! See the '4' card? We put it on our board, and then we add one big bar of ten beads and four little beads. That makes fourteen – ten and four!

slides.text: Build 15: 'Ten and five — FIFTEEN!' Build 16: 'Ten and six — SIXTEEN!'
slides.mascot_explanation: We're going to keep building! First, we'll make fifteen, which is ten and five beads, and then we'll make sixteen, which is ten and six beads. We're becoming number builders!

slides.text: Notice the pattern: 'Four-teen has four. Five-teen... we say fifteen. Six-teen has six.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Isn't it funny how the numbers sound? "Four-teen" has a "four" in it, and "six-teen" has a "six." "Fifteen" is a little tricky, but it's still ten and five!

slides.prompt: I say a number, you build it! 'Build fourteen!' 'Now thirteen!' Mix them up for a challenge.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's your turn to be the builder! I'll say a number, and you build it using the board and beads. Let's try building fourteen, and then maybe thirteen! You can do it!

slides.text: 'Six teen numbers so far — 11 through 16! You are counting past ten!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child form and name numbers 11-16?
slides.mascot_explanation: You did it! We learned all about numbers eleven, twelve, thirteen, fourteen, fifteen, and sixteen! That's so many numbers past ten, you're getting so big and smart!

parent_notes: Notice the naming pattern: 13 (three-teen), 14 (four-teen), 15 (fif-teen), 16 (six-teen). The names become more regular after the tricky 11 and 12. Point out this pattern to help the child predict future teen names. The concrete beads make it clear that each teen number is 'ten and some more.'

title: Parts of a Plant — Root, Stem, Leaf, Flower
description: Introduction to the four main parts of a plant. The child examines a real plant and learns the function of each part using Montessori nomenclature cards.
instructions:
1. Place a whole plant (with roots visible) on the work mat.
2. Point to each part: 'This is the root. It drinks water from the soil.'
3. 'This is the stem. It holds the plant up and carries water to the leaves.'
4. 'These are the leaves. They make food from sunlight.'
5. 'This is the flower. It makes seeds for new plants.'
6. Match nomenclature cards to the real plant parts.
materials_needed: A whole plant with visible roots (pulled from soil or a seedling in water)

slides.heading: Parts of a Plant
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at this big word: "Parts of a Plant"! We're going to learn all about the different pieces that make a plant grow big and strong, like the roots, stem, leaves, and flower!

items: A real plant with visible roots
slides.setup_instructions: Gently pull a small plant from soil or use a seedling grown in water so roots are visible. Lay it on the mat.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, let's get our special plant ready! We need our plant so we can see all its parts, some special picture cards, a magnifying glass to look super close, and a mat to keep everything tidy. Can you ask your grown-up to help you find these things?

slides.text: 'Plants have parts, just like our body has parts. Let's learn the four main parts of a plant!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Just like you have hands and feet and a nose, plants have different parts too! We're going to learn the names of the four most important parts of a plant today.

slides.text: Touch the roots: 'These are the ROOTS. They grow under the ground and drink water for the plant.' Look with the magnifying glass.
slides.mascot_explanation: See these wiggly things down here? These are the ROOTS! They live under the dirt and slurp up water like a straw, giving the plant a big drink. Let's use our magnifying glass to see them up close!

slides.text: Touch the stem: 'This is the STEM. It's like the plant's backbone — it holds everything up and carries water from the roots to the leaves.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now, let's look at this long part going up from the roots. This is the STEM! It's like the plant's body, holding it tall so it can reach the sun and carrying water up to the leaves.

slides.text: Touch a leaf: 'These are the LEAVES. They make food for the plant using sunlight!' Touch the flower if present: 'The FLOWER makes seeds.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Look at these green parts – those are the LEAVES! They are like little chefs, using sunshine to make yummy food for the plant. And if there's a pretty FLOWER, that part helps make seeds so new plants can grow!

slides.prompt: Match the nomenclature cards to the real plant parts. Then draw and label your own plant with all four parts!
slides.mascot_explanation: Now for the fun part! Let's take our picture cards and put them right next to the part of the plant that matches. After that, we can draw our own plant and label all the parts we learned!

slides.text: 'Root, stem, leaf, flower — every plant has these parts working together!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child name and point to all four parts of a plant?
slides.mascot_explanation: Yay, we did it! We learned all about the roots, stem, leaves, and flower. You are such a super plant expert now, remembering all the plant's special parts!

parent_notes: Using a real plant makes this lesson concrete and memorable. Bean sprouts or herbs from the garden work well because the roots are easy to see. Nomenclature cards are a Montessori staple: each card has a picture with one part highlighted and its label. You can make these at home by printing and labeling simple plant diagrams. This lesson connects beautifully to The Tiny Seed read-aloud.

title: Watercolor Techniques — Wet on Wet
description: Introduction to watercolor painting using the wet-on-wet technique. The child learns to prepare the paper, wet it with a sponge, and apply color.
instructions:
1. Show the watercolor supplies: paints, brush, water cup, paper, sponge.
2. Demonstrate wetting the paper evenly with the damp sponge.
3. Dip the brush in water, then into paint. Touch the wet paper — 'Watch the color spread!'
4. Show how to rinse the brush between colors.
5. Let the child paint freely on wet paper.
6. Observe how colors blend and flow together.

slides.heading: Watercolor Painting
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at this! We're going to paint with special colors called watercolors today, and it's going to be super fun! We'll learn a cool way to make the colors spread out like magic.

slides.setup_instructions: Cover the table. Put on a smock. Fill the water cup. Lay out paints and paper.
slides.mascot_explanation: Let's get our art supplies ready! We need those colorful paint pots, a special kind of paper, a brush for painting, a cup for water, and a sponge to make things wet. Oh, and we should wear a smock to keep our clothes nice and clean! Ask a grown-up to help you gather everything.

slides.text: 'Today we are going to paint with watercolors! First, we make our paper WET.' Dampen the sponge and stroke it across the paper.
slides.mascot_explanation: First, we need to get our paper all wet and ready for painting. See this soft sponge? We'll dip it in a little bit of water and gently pat it all over the paper. This makes the paper ready for our colors to dance!

slides.text: 'Now dip the brush in water, then into the paint. Touch the wet paper gently and watch!' The color flows and spreads.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now for the fun part! We take our brush, give it a little drink of water, and then pick up some bright paint. When we touch the brush to our wet paper, watch the color spread out like a happy puddle!

slides.text: 'To change colors, rinse your brush in the water cup. Dip into the new color. See how they blend on the wet paper!'
slides.mascot_explanation: When we want to use a different color, we need to give our brush a little bath in the water cup first. Then we can pick up a new color and paint! See how the new color plays with the old color on the wet paper?

slides.prompt: Paint freely on your wet paper. Try two or three colors. What happens where the colors meet?
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's your turn to be the artist! You can paint whatever you like on your wet paper, and try using two or three colors. See what happens when the colors touch each other – it’s like they’re giving each other a hug!

slides.text: Let the painting dry flat. Rinse the brush and clean up. 'Watercolors are magical — the colors flow like rivers!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child wet paper, apply paint, and rinse the brush between colors?
slides.mascot_explanation: Great job painting! We'll let our beautiful picture dry flat, and then we clean up our brushes. Wasn't it amazing how the colors flowed and mixed together like magic rivers on the paper? You did such a wonderful job painting!

parent_notes: Wet-on-wet watercolor is a Waldorf and Montessori staple. It produces beautiful, flowing results even for beginners, building confidence. The key skills are: wetting paper evenly, using enough water on the brush, and rinsing between colors. Accept that the paper will buckle — use thicker paper or watercolor paper for better results. Display the painting proudly when dry.

title: Sewing — Running Stitch Practice on Burlap
description: Practicing the running stitch on burlap with increasing independence, focusing on even stitch length and tension.
instructions:
1. Prepare a burlap square with a simple straight-line pattern drawn or traced.
2. Thread the needle with yarn. Tie a large knot at the end.
3. Demonstrate: push the needle up from the back, pull through, push down a short distance away, pull through.
4. 'Up, down, up, down — this is called a running stitch.'
5. Let the child practice along the drawn line.
6. Tie off the end when finished.

slides.heading: Sewing
slides.subheading: Sewing — Running Stitch Practice on Burlap
slides.mascot_explanation: Look at this fun word! It says "Sewing" – that's what we're going to do today! It's like drawing with a needle and thread to make cool things.

slides.setup_instructions: Draw a straight line on the burlap. Thread the needle and tie a knot. Optional: secure burlap in an embroidery hoop.
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, we have some special things for our sewing adventure! We have a piece of bumpy cloth called burlap with a line, a special needle that's not too pointy, and some soft yarn. Ask your grown-up to help you get these ready!

slides.text: 'Today we are going to learn to sew! Sewing uses a needle and thread to connect fabric.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Today we get to be super sewers! Sewing is like using a special tool, a needle, and string to put two pieces of cloth together, or just to make a pretty line.

slides.text: Show the threaded needle. 'Watch: I push the needle UP through the fabric from behind.' Pull the yarn through.
slides.mascot_explanation: Watch me! I'm going to take my needle and push it UP through the bumpy cloth from the back, like a little surprise coming out. Then I pull the yarn through.

slides.text: 'Now I push the needle DOWN through the fabric a little bit forward.' Pull through. 'Up, down, up, down.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now, I'm going to poke the needle DOWN into the cloth just a little way ahead of where it came out. Then I pull the yarn through again. See? Up, then down!

slides.text: 'This is called a RUNNING STITCH. It looks like dashes on top and dashes on the bottom.'
slides.mascot_explanation: This special way of sewing is called a running stitch! It makes little dash marks going through the cloth, like a tiny train track. Up, down, up, down makes our train track!

slides.prompt: Sew along the line using the running stitch. Take your time — up, down, up, down. Follow the line!
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's your turn to try! We're going to follow the line on our bumpy cloth, going up and down with our needle, just like we practiced. Take your time and make a beautiful line!

slides.text: When you reach the end, help tie a knot. 'You made your first stitches! You are a sewer!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child independently push the needle up and down to create a running stitch?
slides.mascot_explanation: Yay! You did it! You made your very own stitches, just like a real sewer! You can be so proud of the cool line you made on the bumpy cloth.

parent_notes: Sewing is an excellent Montessori practical life work that develops concentration, hand-eye coordination, and bilateral coordination. Burlap is ideal for beginners because it has large, visible holes. Blunt tapestry needles are safe for children. Keep the yarn relatively short (18 inches) to prevent tangling. This work can be placed on the shelf for independent practice once demonstrated.

title: Moveable Alphabet — CVC Word Lists
description: Building CVC (consonant-vowel-consonant) words with the moveable alphabet, organized by word families: -at, -an, -ig.
instructions:
1. Review the moveable alphabet and how to find letters.
2. 'Today we are going to build word families! Words that rhyme.'
3. Build 'cat.' Change the 'c' to 'b' — 'bat!' Change to 'h' — 'hat!' Change to 's' — 'sat!'
4. Start -an family: can, man, ran, van, fan.
5. Start -ig family: big, dig, pig, wig, fig.
6. Child reads each word as it is built.

slides.heading: Moveable Alphabet
slides.mascot_explanation: Look at this fun title! It tells us we're going to play with letters to make words that sound the same at the end, like rhyming words!

slides.setup_instructions: Clear a large mat. Open the moveable alphabet where the child can reach all compartments.
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at all these special letter pieces! This box has all the letters we need, and this big mat is where we'll put them to build our words. Let's ask a grown-up to help us get them ready!

slides.text: 'Word families are groups of words that sound the same at the end. They RHYME!' Build 'cat' on the mat.
slides.mascot_explanation: Today, we're going to learn about word families! These are words that sound the same at the end, like how "cat" sounds at the end. We'll use our special letters to make "cat" first!

slides.text: 'If I change the first letter to b...' swap c for b, 'now it says BAT! What if I use h?' Hat!
slides.mascot_explanation: Now, watch this! We have "cat," but if we take off the "c" and put a "b" there instead, it says "bat!" See? And if we change it to an "h," it says "hat!"

slides.text: Continue the -at family: sat, mat, rat, pat, fat. 'How many -at words can we make?'
slides.mascot_explanation: We can make even more rhyming words! Let's try changing the first letter to make "sat," "mat," "rat," and "pat." We're making so many words that all sound like "at"!

slides.text: New family! Build 'can.' Change the first letter: man, ran, van, fan, pan. Then try -ig: big, dig, pig, wig.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now we'll try a new word family! We'll start with "can" and change the first letter to make "man," "ran," and "fan." Then we'll make words that sound like "ig," like "big" and "pig"!

slides.prompt: Pick a word family and build as many words as you can! Change only the first letter each time.
slides.mascot_explanation: It's your turn to be the word builder! Pick a word family, like the "at" words or the "ig" words, and try to make as many words as you can by just changing the first letter. You can do it!

slides.text: 'You built so many words today! Word families help us read — if you know 'cat,' you can read 'bat' and 'hat!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child build and read 3+ words in at least two word families?
slides.mascot_explanation: You did such a super job building words today! You learned how knowing "cat" helps you read "bat" and "hat" because they rhyme. You are such a great word builder!

parent_notes: Word families (also called phonograms or rimes) are powerful for reading because they show the child that words follow patterns. Once the child can read 'cat,' they can read bat, hat, mat, sat, rat, fat, and pat — that's 7 words from knowing the pattern! Keep it playful. If the child builds a nonsense word like 'zat,' laugh together and say it's a silly word.

title: Teen Boards — 17, 18, 19
description: Completing the teen board sequence with 17, 18, and 19. The child now knows all teen numbers from 11 to 19.
instructions:
1. Review 11-16 quickly.
2. Build 17: slide '7' card, place ten bar and 7 unit beads. 'Seventeen — ten and seven!'
3. Build 18: 'Eighteen — ten and eight!'
4. Build 19: 'Nineteen — ten and nine!'
5. Full sequence: build all nine teen numbers in order.
6. Random practice: 'Build seventeen!' 'What number is this?'

slides.heading: Teen Boards
slides.mascot_explanation: Look at this! It says "Teen Boards" and shows us the numbers 17, 18, and 19. We're going to learn all about these special numbers today!

slides.setup_instructions: Set up the teen board. Have plenty of unit beads available (up to 9).
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at all these fun things we need! We have a special board for our numbers, some little number cards, and some long "ten bars" and tiny "unit beads." Ask your grown-up to help you find these so we can play!

slides.text: Quick review: build 11 through 16 with the child. Celebrate how much they know!
slides.mascot_explanation: Let's remember the numbers we already know! We're going to quickly make numbers 11, 12, 13, 14, 15, and 16. You're so smart and know so many numbers already!

slides.text: Build 17: slide the '7' over. 'Seven-teen! Ten and seven.' Place a ten bar and 7 unit beads.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now let's make the number seventeen! See the '7' card? We put it next to the ten bar and add seven little beads. That makes seventeen – it's ten and seven all together!

slides.text: Build 18: 'Eight-teen! Ten and eight.' Build 19: 'Nine-teen! Ten and nine.' 'What comes after 19? TWENTY!'
slides.mascot_explanation: We're going to make eighteen and nineteen next! Eighteen is ten and eight, and nineteen is ten and nine. Wow, after nineteen comes the super exciting number twenty!

slides.text: 'Let's count all the teen numbers: 11, 12, 13, 14, 15, 16, 17, 18, 19!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Let's count all the way through the teen numbers together, from the beginning to the end! We'll say 11, 12, 13, 14, 15, 16, 17, 18, and 19!

slides.prompt: Build all teen numbers in order. Then I'll call out random numbers — build them as fast as you can!
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's time for a fun game! We'll build all the teen numbers in order, and then I'll call out a number and you have to build it super fast! You can do it!

slides.text: 'You know ALL the teen numbers! From 11 to 19. Every single one!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child build and name any teen number from 11-19?
slides.mascot_explanation: Yay! You did it! You know all the teen numbers, from 11 all the way to 19! That's so amazing, you're a super math star!

parent_notes: Completing the teen boards is a milestone. The child now understands that each teen number is composed of ten plus additional units. This understanding is crucial for place value. After 19, the next step will be the ten boards (10, 20, 30...). Play teen number games throughout the day: 'You ate 14 grapes!' 'There are 17 steps!'

title: Puzzle Map — World Continents
description: Introduction to the Montessori world puzzle map. The child removes and replaces continent pieces, reinforcing continent names, shapes, and locations.
instructions:
1. Present the world puzzle map.
2. 'This is a map of our whole world! Let's find each continent.'
3. Remove North America first. Name it and describe its shape.
4. Replace it. Remove South America. Continue with each continent.
5. Remove all continents. Can the child replace them all?
6. Name the oceans between the continents.

slides.heading: Puzzle Map
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at this! This is a special puzzle, and it shows us our whole, big world! We call it the Puzzle Map of the World, and today we're going to learn about the big pieces of land called continents.

slides.setup_instructions: Place the puzzle map on a table or large mat. Ensure the child can reach all pieces.
slides.mascot_explanation: We need our special world puzzle map for our game today! We also need a nice, flat spot to play, like a table or a big mat. If you want, a grown-up can help you look at a picture of the map, called a control map, to help you remember where things go.

slides.text: 'This is a puzzle map of the world. Each colored piece is a continent. Let's name them as we take them out.'
slides.mascot_explanation: This is our amazing world puzzle! See all the different colored pieces? Each one is a big piece of land called a continent, and we're going to learn their names and shapes together. Let's take them out one by one!

slides.text: Remove North America (orange): 'This is North America — where we live! Look at its shape.' Replace it.
slides.mascot_explanation: Look, this big orange piece is called North America, and guess what? It's where we live! Let's feel its shape and then put it right back in its spot, like a puzzle piece.

slides.text: Continue with each continent, removing and replacing one at a time. Name the Montessori color for each.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now we'll take out another piece, and this one is yellow, called Asia! We'll say its name, look at its shape, and then put it back. We'll do this for every single continent, learning their colors and how they fit!

slides.text: Point to the blue areas: 'The blue is OCEAN — water. The Pacific Ocean is the biggest!'
slides.mascot_explanation: See all the blue parts on our map? That's the big, big water called the ocean! The water goes all around the land, and we'll learn the names of some of these oceans too, like the super-duper big Pacific Ocean.

slides.prompt: Remove ALL the continents. Now put them all back! Can you name each one as you place it?
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, your turn to be the puzzle master! Let's take ALL the continent pieces out of the map. Now, can you try to put them all back in their right places? Try to say the name of each continent as you put it back. You can do it!

slides.text: 'You can build the whole world with this map! Seven continents and five oceans.'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child name and correctly place at least 5 of the 7 continents?
slides.mascot_explanation: You did such a great job building the whole world with our puzzle! You learned about all seven continents and the five big oceans. Putting all those pieces back was like putting our whole planet together – you're a super geographer!

parent_notes: Puzzle maps are one of the most popular Montessori materials. The knob on each piece allows easy removal and replacement. The physical act of picking up a continent piece helps the child feel its shape and size. If you don't have a Montessori puzzle map, use a foam world puzzle or print continent shapes to cut out. The Montessori colors are consistent: North America=orange, South America=pink, Europe=red, Asia=yellow, Africa=green, Oceania=brown, Antarctica=white.

title: Read-Aloud: The Reason for a Flower by Ruth Heller
description: Reading 'The Reason for a Flower' by Ruth Heller, a beautifully illustrated nonfiction book about plant parts, pollination, and how flowers become fruits and seeds.
instructions:
1. Show the cover. 'What do you think the reason for a flower is?'
2. Read aloud, pausing at Ruth Heller's gorgeous illustrations.
3. Point out the plant parts as they are introduced: petals, stamens, pistils.
4. Discuss pollination: 'How do bees help flowers?'
5. Connect to seeds and fruits: 'So a flower's reason is to make seeds!'
6. If available, examine a real flower and find the parts.
materials_needed: The Reason for a Flower by Ruth Heller
Optional: a real flower to dissect

slides.heading: Read-Aloud
slides.subheading: The Reason for a Flower by Ruth Heller
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at this pretty book cover! It's called "The Reason for a Flower." We're going to read a story together about why flowers are so special. What do YOU think a flower's special reason might be? Let's find out!

items: The Reason for a Flower book
slides.setup_instructions: Have the book ready. If you have a flower, set it aside for after reading.
slides.mascot_explanation: We're going to read a wonderful book today! See this book right here? That's the one we'll read. And look, if you have a real flower, we can look at it up close later, too! Isn't that exciting?

slides.text: Cover: 'What do you think the reason for a flower is? Let's find out!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now we get to open the book! We'll read the words and look at all the beautiful pictures. As we read, we'll think about why flowers are here. What do you think their job is? Let's discover it together!

slides.text: Read slowly — Ruth Heller's rhyming text and detailed illustrations deserve time. Point out plant parts as they appear.
slides.mascot_explanation: We're going to read this page slowly, looking at all the amazing pictures. We'll point out the parts of the flower as we see them, like the colorful petals. It's like a treasure hunt for flower parts!

slides.text: Discuss: 'What is the flower's job? How do bees help? What happens after the flower is pollinated?'
slides.mascot_explanation: Let's talk about what we're learning! We'll think about what a flower does. We'll also talk about how busy bees help the flowers. And we'll find out what happens after the bees visit!

slides.prompt: If you have a real flower, gently take it apart. Can you find the petals, the stem, the stamens? Draw and label a flower.
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at this real flower! Let's gently touch its soft petals. Can you help me find the middle part? We can even try to draw our own flower and show all its special parts. This is so fun!

slides.text: 'Flowers are beautiful, but they also have an important job — making seeds so new plants can grow!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child explain that flowers help make seeds?
slides.mascot_explanation: We learned that flowers have a super important job! They help make seeds so new flowers can grow. Aren't flowers amazing? You did such a great job learning all about them!

parent_notes: Ruth Heller's nonfiction picture books are stunning and scientifically accurate. This book connects beautifully to botany studies in the Montessori curriculum. The rhyming text makes scientific concepts accessible. Consider pairing with a real flower dissection for hands-on learning.

title: Food Preparation — Spreading Variety (Cream Cheese and Hummus)
description: Practicing spreading skills with different textures: cream cheese, hummus, and other spreads on crackers and bread.
instructions:
1. Wash hands together.
2. Arrange materials on a tray: crackers, small bowl of spread, butter knife, plate.
3. Demonstrate: hold the cracker in one hand, scoop a small amount of spread with the knife.
4. Spread from the center outward. 'Use gentle pressure — the cracker can break!'
5. Place the prepared cracker on the plate.
6. Child prepares their own crackers for snack.
materials_needed: Soft spread (cream cheese, hummus, or butter)

slides.heading: Food Preparation
slides.subheading: Food Preparation — Spreading Variety (Cream Cheese and Hummus)
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at this! We're going to have so much fun making yummy snacks today. We'll learn how to spread yummy things like cream cheese and hummus, just like a big helper!

slides.setup_instructions: Wash hands. Place a small amount of spread in the bowl. Arrange everything on a tray.
slides.mascot_explanation: Let's get our special tools ready for spreading! We need some crunchy crackers, a yummy soft spread, a little knife for spreading, a bowl to hold the spread, a plate for our finished crackers, and a tray to keep everything tidy. Can you help a grown-up find all these things?

slides.text: 'Today we are going to prepare crackers with a spread. First, hold the cracker flat in your hand.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, our hands are all clean! Now, let's pick up a cracker. We need to hold it nice and flat in our hand, like we're holding a little boat.

slides.text: 'Scoop a SMALL amount of spread with the knife. Just a little — you can always add more.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now, let's dip our little knife into the yummy spread. We only want to get a *tiny* bit on the knife, like a little caterpillar. We can always get more if we need it!

slides.text: 'Spread from the middle out to the edges. Be gentle — crackers can break if you press too hard!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Time to spread! Let's gently move the knife from the middle of the cracker out to the edges. Remember to be super gentle, like you're petting a kitty, so our cracker doesn't get a boo-boo and break!

slides.text: Show the finished cracker. 'Beautiful! Now you try. Prepare as many crackers as you would like for your snack.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Look at that! You made a perfectly spread cracker! That looks so yummy and beautiful. Now it's your turn to make some more for our snack time.

slides.prompt: Prepare 4-6 crackers with spread. Practice using gentle pressure. Arrange them nicely on your plate.
slides.mascot_explanation: Yay, you get to make your own yummy crackers! Let's make 4 or 6 of them, spreading gently so they don't break, and then put them all on your plate. You're doing such a great job!

slides.text: Enjoy your snack! Then wash the knife, bowl, and plate. Wipe the tray clean.
slides.mastery_check: Can the child spread without breaking the cracker and clean up independently?
slides.mascot_explanation: You did it! Your crackers look amazing, and you spread them so nicely! Now you get to enjoy your yummy snack. After that, we'll help clean up our tools so they're ready for next time.

parent_notes: Spreading is a wonderful fine motor exercise that also produces a real snack — natural motivation! Choose sturdy crackers that resist breaking. Cream cheese and hummus are both easy spreads for beginners. The challenge of using gentle pressure teaches the child to modulate force. This can become a regular snack-time independence activity.

title: CVC Words — Object to Word Matching
description: The child matches small objects to written CVC words, building the connection between written and spoken language.
instructions:
1. Place 6 small objects on a mat: cat (toy), hat, cup, pen, dog, mop.
2. Write or print 6 CVC word cards: cat, hat, cup, pen, dog, mop.
3. Place the word cards face up.
4. Point to 'cat': sound it out together: /k/-/a/-/t/. 'Which object is cat?'
5. Child matches all 6 objects to word cards.
6. Extension: child reads the words independently first, then finds the object.

slides.heading: CVC Words
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at this! It says "CVC Words," and that's like a special name for short, little words we are going to learn to read. We're going to play a fun game to match words to toys!

items: 6 miniature objects: cat, hat, cup, pen, dog, mop
slides.setup_instructions: Arrange objects in a row. Place word cards face up below them in scrambled order.
slides.mascot_explanation: Look at all these fun things we need for our game! We have a little toy cat, a tiny hat, a little cup, a pen, a small dog toy, and a mop. We also have some cards with words on them. Can you ask a grown-up to help you find these special things?

slides.text: 'Here are some objects and some words. Let's read the words and find the matching objects!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Yay, our game is ready! We have our toys and our word cards. We are going to be word detectives and find out which toy matches each word. Let's look at the words together!

slides.text: Point to the first word card: 'Let's sound it out: /k/-/a/-/t/. Cat! Which object is a cat?' Child places object on the card.
slides.mascot_explanation: See this first word? Let's sound it out like little secret sounds: c-a-t. That spells "cat"! Now, can you find the toy cat and put it right on top of the word "cat"? Great job!

slides.text: Continue with each word. Let the child try sounding out independently before helping.
slides.mascot_explanation: We did so well with the cat! Now let's do the same for all the other words. We'll sound them out together, and you can be a super matcher and find the right toy for each word. You can do it!

slides.text: Extension: scramble everything. Child reads each word card on their own and places the matching object.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now you're getting so good at this! This time, you get to be the reader. You'll look at each word all by yourself, sound it out, and then find the toy that goes with it. You are becoming a super reader!

slides.prompt: Match all 6 objects to their words. Then try: I'll say a word, you find BOTH the card and the object!
slides.mascot_explanation: This is the big challenge! We need to match all the toys to their words. Then, I'll say a word, and you have to find both the word card *and* the toy that matches it. You can do it, I know you can!

slides.text: 'You are READING words and matching them to real things! That is what reading is all about!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child read and match at least 4 out of 6 CVC words?
slides.mascot_explanation: You did such an amazing job today! You learned how to read words and match them to real things, just like a big kid! You are such a good reader, and I am so proud of you!

parent_notes: Object-to-word matching is a critical Montessori reading activity. It connects the abstract (written word) to the concrete (real object). Use objects the child can name easily. If you don't have miniatures, use photos or real items from around the house. The child sounding out the word independently — even haltingly — is a huge milestone. Celebrate every attempt!

title: Ten Boards — Introduction (10-50)
description: Introduction to the Montessori ten boards (tens boards). The child learns the names of the tens: 10, 20, 30, 40, 50, and builds them with bead bars.
instructions:
1. Present the ten board showing '10' repeated.
2. Point to the first 10: 'Ten.' Slide '2' to make 20: 'Twenty — two tens!'
3. Place 2 ten bead bars beside it.
4. Continue: 30 (three tens), 40 (four tens), 50 (five tens).
5. Three-period lesson: 'This is thirty. Show me fifty. What is this?'
6. Count the bead bars for each number.

slides.heading: Ten Boards
slides.mascot_explanation: Look at this fun slide! It shows us the special numbers we are going to learn today: 10, 20, 30, 40, and 50. These are big, important numbers that help us count even more things!

slides.setup_instructions: Place the ten board on the mat. Have 5 ten bars ready in a tray.
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at all the things we get to use for our game! We have a special board, some number cards, and these long, shiny bars. These bars are made of ten little beads, and they will help us build our big numbers!

slides.text: 'You know teen numbers — now let's learn the BIG tens! Ten, twenty, thirty, forty, fifty.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now we get to learn about the big tens! We already know about numbers like 11 and 12, but these numbers are even bigger. We are going to learn the names: ten, twenty, thirty, forty, and fifty!

slides.text: Point to 10 on the board. 'This is ten — one ten.' Place one ten bar beside it.
slides.mascot_explanation: See this number on the board? It says '10'. This is our first big number, and it means we have one group of ten. We'll put one shiny ten bar next to it to show it's ten!

slides.text: Make 20: 'Twenty means TWO tens!' Place 2 ten bars. Make 30: 'THREE tens — thirty!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now we make the next number, twenty! Twenty is like having two groups of ten, so we put two shiny ten bars here. And look, this number is thirty, which means we have three groups of ten!

slides.text: Continue to 40 and 50. Count the ten bars each time: 'One ten, two tens, three tens — thirty!'
slides.mascot_explanation: We keep going to learn forty and fifty! Each time, we count how many shiny ten bars we have. We say 'one ten, two tens, three tens,' and that helps us know the big number we are making!

slides.prompt: Build each number with ten bars. Then play: 'Show me forty!' 'How many tens make fifty?'
slides.mascot_explanation: It's time to play! We get to build the numbers ourselves using the shiny ten bars. You can show me forty, and I'll ask you how many tens are in fifty. Let's build them together!

slides.text: '10, 20, 30, 40, 50 — each one is made of groups of TEN! Next time we'll go all the way to 100!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child name and build 10-50 using ten bars?
slides.mascot_explanation: You did such a great job! We learned that 10, 20, 30, 40, and 50 are all made of groups of ten. It's like magic how we can make such big numbers! Next time, we'll learn even bigger numbers!

parent_notes: The ten board helps children understand our base-10 number system. Each ten has a name (twenty, thirty, etc.) and can be seen as a group of ten-bars. The concrete bead bars make this visible and tangible. Twenty is literally two ten-bars side by side. This understanding of place value is essential for all future math.

title: Flags of the World — Introduction
description: Introduction to world flags. The child learns that each country has its own flag and explores the flags of 4-5 countries, starting with their own.
instructions:
1. Show your country's flag. 'This is the flag of our country. Each country has its own special flag.'
2. Discuss colors and symbols: 'What colors do you see? What shapes?'
3. Introduce 3-4 more flags: Canada, Mexico, Japan, Brazil.
4. Match flags to continents on the puzzle map.
5. 'Flags tell us about a country's story.'
6. Child draws their favorite flag.
materials_needed: Small flags or flag cards (5-6 countries)
Paper and crayons for flag drawing

slides.heading: Flags of the World
slides.mascot_explanation: Look at this fun page! It says "Flags of the World," and it means we're going on an adventure to see special flags from all around our big, big Earth. It also says "Every Country Has a Flag," which means every place has its own special picture to show everyone who it is!

items: 5-6 small flags or printed flag cards
slides.setup_instructions: Select flags with distinctive, simple designs. Have the puzzle map nearby.
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at all these cool things we need for our flag adventure! We have some little flags, like tiny pictures of countries, and a big puzzle map of the whole world. We also have paper and crayons, so we can make our own art later. Ask your grown-up to help you find these things so we can start playing!

slides.text: Show your country's flag: 'This is OUR flag! It has [describe colors and symbols]. Every country in the world has its own flag.'
slides.mascot_explanation: This is our country's flag! See all its special colors and shapes? It's like our country's special hello to everyone else. Every country has a flag just like this one, to show they are unique and special.

slides.text: Show Japan's flag: 'A white flag with a red circle — the sun!' Place it on Asia on the map.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now we see the flag of Japan! It's white with a big red circle in the middle, like a happy sun. Let's find Japan on our big puzzle map, way over in a part called Asia, and put this flag there!

slides.text: Show Brazil's flag: 'Green, yellow, blue, and white — with stars!' Place it on South America.
slides.mascot_explanation: Here is the flag of Brazil! It has so many colors – green, yellow, and blue, plus some little white stars. Can you find Brazil on our map in a place called South America? Let's put this flag right there!

slides.text: Continue with 2-3 more flags. Match each to its continent on the puzzle map.
slides.mascot_explanation: We've seen our flag, Japan's, and Brazil's! Now we get to look at a couple more special flags and find them on our big world map. It's like a treasure hunt to find where each flag belongs!

slides.prompt: Choose your favorite flag and draw it! Try to match the colors and shapes. Which flag do you like best?
slides.mascot_explanation: Isn't drawing fun? Now it's your turn to pick your favorite flag we saw and draw it on your paper. Try to make the colors and shapes just right, like the real flag! Which flag do you like the very best?

slides.text: 'Flags are beautiful and each one tells a story about its country. We will learn more flags this year!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child identify at least 3 flags and match them to their continent?
slides.mascot_explanation: We did such a great job looking at all those flags today! Each flag tells a little story about its country, like a secret code. You were so good at finding them on the map, and we'll learn even more flags together next time!

parent_notes: Children are often fascinated by flags. Start with simple, distinctive flags (Japan's circle, Canada's maple leaf) before more complex designs. Flag work connects geography, culture, art, and fine motor skills (drawing flags). You can make a flag book or flag display. Miniature flags on toothpicks stuck in clay are wonderful for matching to the puzzle map.

title: Watercolor Techniques — Color Mixing on Paper
description: Exploring color mixing with watercolors. The child paints two colors side by side and watches them blend to create a new color.
instructions:
1. Set up watercolor supplies.
2. Review wet-on-wet technique from earlier this week.
3. 'Let's discover what happens when colors meet!' Paint a stripe of yellow, then a stripe of blue touching it.
4. Watch where they meet: 'Green! Yellow and blue make green!'
5. Try red + yellow = orange. Red + blue = purple.
6. Free painting using all the new colors.

slides.heading: Watercolor Painting
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at this colorful slide! It says "Watercolor Painting" and "Color Mixing Magic." That means we get to do some super fun painting and make magic colors happen on our paper!

slides.setup_instructions: Set up painting area. Wet the paper lightly with the sponge.
slides.mascot_explanation: Oh, look at all our special painting things! We have our paint colors, our special paper, a brush to paint with, a cup for water, a sponge to make the paper a little wet, and a smock to keep our clothes clean. Let's ask a grown-up to help us get all these ready for painting fun!

slides.text: 'Today we are going to make NEW colors! Watch this.' Paint yellow on one side of the wet paper.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's time to make some magic! See this yellow paint? We're going to paint a nice stripe of yellow right here on our paper. Don't worry, the paper is a little wet, which helps the colors do their magic!

slides.text: Paint blue right next to the yellow. 'Look where they meet — what color do you see?' GREEN!
slides.mascot_explanation: Now, let's paint some blue right next to our yellow stripe. Watch what happens where the yellow and blue colors touch! Ooh, they are making a brand new color! Can you see it? It's GREEN!

slides.text: On a new paper: red + yellow = orange! Red + blue = purple! 'We made THREE new colors from THREE primary colors!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Let's try some more magic on a new piece of paper! If we mix red and yellow, we get ORANGE! And if we mix red and blue, we get PURPLE! We just made three new colors from the first three colors!

slides.prompt: Create a painting using both primary and mixed colors. How many different colors can you make?
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's your turn to be the color magician! You can paint anything you like, using the yellow, blue, and red, and all the new colors we made like green, orange, and purple. Let's see how many different colors you can paint with!

slides.text: 'Red, yellow, and blue are PRIMARY colors. When we mix them, we make SECONDARY colors: green, orange, purple!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child create at least 2 secondary colors by mixing primaries?
slides.mascot_explanation: You did such a wonderful job painting today! We learned that red, yellow, and blue are called primary colors, and when we mixed them, we made secondary colors like green, orange, and purple! You were a real color mixing star!

parent_notes: Color mixing with watercolors is more magical than with other media because the colors blend naturally on wet paper. This connects to the sensorial color tablet work. Use the correct vocabulary: primary colors (red, yellow, blue) and secondary colors (green, orange, purple). Keep extra paper handy — children often want to experiment repeatedly!

title: Sound Cylinders — Matching and Memory Game
description: Using the sound cylinders in a matching game, shaking and listening carefully to pair identical sounds from the two boxes, then playing a memory-style game.
instructions:
1. Present the two boxes of sound cylinders (one with red lids, one with blue lids).
2. Shake one red cylinder. Shake each blue cylinder until a match is found.
3. 'Listen carefully — do these sound the same?' Place matches together.
4. Continue until all pairs are matched.
5. Grade from softest to loudest.
6. Three-period lesson: 'This is loud. This is soft. Which is louder?'

slides.heading: Sound Cylinders
slides.subheading: Sound Cylinders — Matching and Memory Game
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at this! Today, we get to play a super fun game with our ears called Sound Cylinders! We're going to be listening detectives to find pairs that sound just the same.

items: Sound cylinders — red set and blue set (6 each)
slides.setup_instructions: Place red cylinders on one side, blue on the other. Ensure a quiet room for listening.
slides.mascot_explanation: We need some special things for our listening game! See these little tubes with red tops and blue tops? Those are our sound cylinders, and they make different noises when we shake them. We also have a mat to help keep everything neat while we play. Can you ask a grown-up to help you find these?

slides.text: 'Today we are going to use our EARS! These cylinders each make a different sound. Let's find the matches.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Today is all about using our amazing ears! These little tubes have surprises inside that make sounds. Our job is to be super listeners and find two tubes that sound exactly alike when we shake them.

slides.text: Shake one red cylinder near your ear. 'Listen to this sound.' Now shake each blue cylinder. 'Does THIS one match?'
slides.mascot_explanation: Let's start with one of the red tubes. Hold it close to your ear and give it a gentle shake. Now, we take a blue tube and shake it near your ear. Do they sound the same? We have to listen very, very carefully!

slides.text: When a match is found: 'Yes! These sound the same!' Place them together in the center.
slides.mascot_explanation: Yay, you found one! If two tubes sound just like twins, that means they are a match. We put the matching ones together right in the middle, like a special pair.

slides.text: Continue matching all 6 pairs. 'Your ears are like scientists — listening and comparing!'
slides.mascot_explanation: We keep shaking and listening to find all the matches. It's like a treasure hunt for sounds! You are doing such a great job using your super listening skills to find all the pairs.

slides.prompt: Match all the pairs. Then put them in order from softest to loudest. Can you hear the differences?
slides.mascot_explanation: Now that we've found all the matching pairs, we get to do something extra cool! We'll listen to them again and try to put them in order from the quietest sound to the loudest sound. It's like making a sound rainbow!

slides.text: 'You matched all the sounds! Your ears can hear very small differences.'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child correctly match at least 4 of the 6 sound pairs?
slides.mascot_explanation: You did it! You matched all the sound pairs, and you were so good at listening for the tiny differences. Your ears are amazing, like a super detective's ears!

parent_notes: Sound cylinders train auditory discrimination, which supports phonemic awareness and music appreciation. The room must be quiet for this work. If you don't have Montessori sound cylinders, make your own: fill opaque containers (film canisters, small bottles) in matching pairs with rice, beans, sand, bells, beads, and salt. The child should not be able to see inside. This is a wonderful independent activity once demonstrated.

title: CVC Word Reading — Short Sentences
description: The child begins reading simple sentences made of CVC words: 'The cat sat.' Building from word reading to sentence reading.
instructions:
1. Review reading 5-6 CVC words.
2. Introduce sight words: 'the', 'a', 'is', 'on'. 'Some words we just learn by sight.'
3. Build a sentence with the moveable alphabet or word cards: 'The cat sat.'
4. Child reads the sentence. Act it out!
5. Build more: 'A dog ran.' 'The pig is big.'
6. Child illustrates their favorite sentence.
materials_needed: Moveable alphabet or printed word cards
Sight word cards (the, a, is, on)

slides.heading: Reading Sentences
slides.mascot_explanation: Look at this fun page! We're going to learn how to read special sentences that tell us a whole story, just like when we read a book!

slides.setup_instructions: Prepare word cards for common CVC words and sight words. Lay out on a mat.
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at all these cool letter pieces! We have letters to make words, special cards for little words like "the," and paper and crayons for drawing. You'll need these to make our sentences, so ask a grown-up to help you find them!

slides.text: 'You can read words! Now let's put words together to make SENTENCES — sentences tell us something.'
slides.mascot_explanation: You are so good at reading words! Now we get to put those words together to make something even bigger and more exciting: sentences! Sentences are like little stories that tell us what's happening.

slides.text: Show sight word cards: 'the' and 'a.' 'These little words help sentences work. We learn them by looking at them many times.'
slides.mascot_explanation: See these little word cards? This one says "the" and this one says "a." They are like magic helpers that make our sentences sound just right. We just have to remember what they look like!

slides.text: Build: 'The cat sat.' Point to each word. Child reads each word, then the whole sentence. 'The cat sat! Can you sit like a cat?'
slides.mascot_explanation: Look, we made a sentence together: "The cat sat." Can you point to each word and say it with me? The... cat... sat! Great job! Now, can you pretend to sit like a little cat? Meow!

slides.text: Build more sentences: 'A dog ran.' 'The pig is big.' 'A man sat on a mat.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Let's try building some more super sentences! We can make "A dog ran," and "The pig is big." We can even make our own new sentences with these word pieces!

slides.prompt: Read each sentence. Pick your favorite and draw a picture of it! Can you build your OWN sentence?
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's your turn to be the sentence reader and artist! Read each sentence we make, and then pick your favorite one to draw a picture of. Maybe you can even try to build your very own sentence all by yourself!

slides.text: 'You are reading SENTENCES! Words make sentences, and sentences tell stories!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child read at least 2 simple CVC sentences?
slides.mascot_explanation: Yay! You did it! You are a super sentence reader now! You learned how words can join together to tell us stories, and that's amazing! Remember how you read "The cat sat" and drew a picture? You're a star!

parent_notes: Moving from single words to sentences is a thrilling milestone. Sight words (the, a, is, on) don't follow simple phonetic rules, so we teach them as whole words. Keep sentences very short at first (3-4 words). Acting out sentences makes them fun and meaningful. If the child can build their own sentence, even a simple one like 'a cat sat,' they are truly writing!

title: Ten Boards — Extension to 100
description: Extending the ten board work through 60, 70, 80, 90, and 100. The child counts by tens to 100 using bead bars.
instructions:
1. Review 10-50 from the previous lesson.
2. Continue: 60 (six tens), 70 (seven tens), 80 (eight tens), 90 (nine tens).
3. Place ten bars in rows for each: 'Count with me: 10, 20, 30, 40, 50, 60, 70, 80, 90!'
4. Introduce 100: 'Ten tens make ONE HUNDRED!' Show the golden bead hundred square.
5. Count by tens to 100.
6. Celebrate reaching 100!

slides.heading: Ten Boards
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at that! This is our special math adventure where we get to count super high, all the way to 100! It's like a big number party!
